questions.text: Which one of the following parameters in a patient on mechanical ventilation satisfies the criteria for extubation?
questions.solution:
The tidal volume of 6ml/kg satisfies the criteria for extubation in a patient on mechanical ventilation.

Extubation criteria:

  • Breathe spontaneously
  • Hemodynamically stable
  • Arterial oxygen saturation >90% on 40–50% O2 with <5 cm H2O of PEEP
  • Arterial blood gas analysis: pH >7.25

Additional criteria include,

  • Inspiratory pressure: < -25 cm H2O
  • Tidal volume: >5 ml/kg
  • Vital capacity: >10 mL/kg
  • Minute ventilation: <10mL
  • Rapid shallow breathing index(RSBI): <100

questions.text:
Match the following sites of cannulations of central venous catheters and their associated complications.

i) Subclavian vein 

ii) Right Internal Jugular vein

iii) Left Internal Jugular vein 

iv) Femoral vein  

a) Increased risk of line-related sepsis

b) Increased risk of pleural effusion 

c) Comparatively safe and easily accessible 

d) Increased risk of pneumothorax
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option D: i-d, ii-c, iii-b, iv-a

i) Subclavian vein  d) Increased risk of pneumothorax 
ii) Right Internal Jugular vein c) Comparatively safe and easily accessible
iii) Left Internal Jugular vein  b) Increased risk of pleural effusion
iv) Femoral vein  a) Increased risk of line-related sepsis


Central venous catheterization is indicated for the administration of vasopressors, medications, and total parenteral nutrition. It is also useful in procedures like dialysis, plasmapheresis, and interventions such as transvenous pacemaker placement.

A central venous catheter (CVC) is an indwelling device inserted into a large, central vein and advanced until the terminal lumen resides within the inferior vena cava, superior vena cava, or right atrium.

Cannulation can be done at various sites, namely the internal jugular, common femoral, and subclavian veins.

  • Subclavian vein: associated with the highest risk of pneumothorax.
  • Right internal jugular vein: most preferred because of its accessibility, low complication rates, and reliable anatomy.
  • Left internal jugular vein: associated with an increased risk of pleural effusion and chylothorax.
  • Femoral vein: associated with an increased risk of infection and line-related sepsis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old was brought to the emergency after a road traffic accident. On examination, his Glasgow coma score was E2V2M4. An NCCT brain was done which is shown in the image below. What grade is given to this patient based on the American Society of Anaesthesiologists (ASA) physical status classification?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 26-year-old with a GCS score of 8 and an NCCT brain revealing an intracranial bleed with significant midline shift is moribund and is not expected to survive without immediate intervention. Hence, ASA V is the grade given to this patient based on the American Society of Anaesthesiologists (ASA) Physical status classification.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about the position of the patient given in the image?

1) Prevents air embolism during central venous catheter placement
2) Widely accepted position to perform pelvic surgeries
3) Contraindicated in patients with shock
4) Helpful in cases with high intracranial pressure
5) Increased risk of aspiration due to high intraabdominal pressure
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Trendelenberg position. Statements 1, 2, and 5 are true with regard to this condition.

The Trendelenberg position is a variation of the supine position in which the patient’s head end is tilted down compared to the leg end. Uses of the Trendelenberg position are:

  • Laparoscopic, pelvic, and abdominal surgeries due to its better exposure (statement 2)
  • Inserting central venous catheters since it prevents air embolism (statement 1)
  • It temporarily increases venous return; hence, it is useful in patients with shock

Respiratory parameters like functional residual capacity are decreased due to the gravitational pull of the diaphragm in this position.

Despite its applications in various scenarios, the Trendelenberg position can increase intraocular and intracranial pressures. Another thing to look out for is the increased risk of aspiration in patients since the Trendelenberg position increases intraabdominal pressure and displaces the stomach (statement 5).

  • Trendelenburg sign: This sign is demonstrated by asking the patient to stand on one limb. When the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis severely drops over the swing limb. This is seen in the paralysis of gluteus medius and minimus, dislocated hip, fracture neck of femur
  • Trendelenburg gait: This gait is seen in patients with Trendelenburg sign. The body swings to the opposite side every time when the weight is borne on the same side. 
  • Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's head is lower than his feet (head-down position)

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about epidural anesthesia when compared to spinal anesthesia.

choices.text: The density of the block is less
Less chances of post-dural puncture headache
More useful in postoperative pain relief

questions.solution:
Epidural anesthesia has a slower onset of action when compared to spinal anesthesia. 

Epidural anesthesia is a method of neuraxial pain control in which anesthetic medications are injected into the epidural space to block sensory and motor spinal nerve roots in the thoracic, abdominal, pelvic, and lower extremity areas. It is widely used for surgical anesthesia, obstetric analgesia, postoperative pain control (option D), and chronic pain management.

In epidural anesthesia, the needle does not penetrate the dura mater; hence, the chances of a post-dural puncture headache are low (option C). However, compared to spinal anesthesia, it has a slower onset of action and a low density of the block (option B). 

The image below is of the 18G Tuohy needle, which is the most common needle used in epidural anesthesia. The needle shaft is calibrated and has a blunt, curved tip (Huber tip) that prevents accidental dural puncture.

questions.text:
On pre-operative assessment, a patient is found to be taking several medications. Which of the following medications cannot be taken on the day of surgery?

1) Loop diuretics
2) Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
3) Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors
4) Beta-blockers
5) Anticonvulsants
questions.solution:
Loop diuretics, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors cannot be taken on the day of surgery. On the other hand, beta-blockers and anticonvulsants can be continued. 

Loop diuretics are not continued during the surgery due to their interaction with the neuromuscular blockers and the risk of electrolyte imbalance (hypokalemia/hyperkalemia). 

Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors are withheld due to the risk of hypotension on induction with anesthesia.

Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDS) are not recommended before surgery, as they may increase the risk of bleeding.

questions.text: The following capnographic waveform is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The given capnographic waveform is suggestive of bronchospasm.

Capnography refers to the method of CO2 measurement as a function of time or volume. Bronchospasms may be due to respiratory pathologies like asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), or acute lung injury. Another cause of this waveform is a partially obstructed endotracheal tube or breathing circuit. Capnographic changes in bronchospasm include:

  • Loss of verticality of Phase II
  • The opening of the angle between phases 2 and 3 (α angle)
  • Increased upslope of phase III
  • No plateau before the next inspiration
  • Shark fin appearance - in severe cases

 Normal capnography is shown in the image below:

Other options:

Option A: Malignant hyperthermia would show a progressive rise in the end-tidal CO2 due to the increased metabolic rate.

Option C: Rebreathing will show the failure of CO2 to return to the baseline at the end of the expiration. The inspiratory CO2 remains above 0.

Option D: Accidental extubation or circuit disconnection would show a sudden cessation of CO2.

questions.text: Mapleson's circuit includes types A, B, C, D, E, and F.  Which of the following is the correct order of efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation?
questions.solution:
The efficiency of  Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is DFE > BC > A. 

The performance of the Mapleson circuit is best studied in the expiratory phase of the respiratory cycle. The efficiency of the Mapleson circuit is determined by the inflow rate required to prevent rebreathing of CO2.

The DEF systems are more efficient than the BC systems. To prevent rebreathing, BC systems require a higher rate of fresh gas inflow than DEF systems. This is because of the pop-off valve present near the fresh gas inflow in BC systems. A significant amount of fresh gas gets vented out through this valve at the end of expiration. In DEF systems, fresh gas flow pushes the exhaled alveolar gas away from the patient and thus reduces rebreathing of CO2.

For Mapleson A circuits, in controlled ventilation, significant rebreathing of CO2 occurs. To prevent this, a very high fresh gas inflow (>20 L/min) is required for Mapleson A. The pop-off valve vents out a significant amount of fresh gas during the inspiratory phase. Thus, Mapleson A has the worst efficiency in controlled ventilation.

During spontaneous breathing, Mapleson A has the best efficiency. During spontaneous ventilation, exhaled alveolar gas is vented through the pop-off during expiration. When the patient inspires, fresh gas is mainly taken in. 

The efficiency of  Mapleson circuits in spontaneous ventilation is  A > DFE > CB.

Remember:

A > DFE > CB : A Dog Can Bite (Usually a spontaneous event)

DFE > BC > A : Dancing Babies can't assist (controlled)

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient has to undergo incisional hernia surgery under general anesthesia. She complains of awareness in her past caesarean section. Which of the following monitoring techniques can be used to prevent such awareness?
questions.solution:
The monitoring technique used to prevent such an awareness intraoperatively is the bispectral index. 

The bispectral index is a monitoring technique to check the depth of anesthesia using an algorithm by a device. Individual intraoperative awareness is evaluated. It utilizes parameters like EEG signals, eye blinking, etc. 

BIS examines four components within the EEG that are associated with the anesthetic state.

  1. Low-frequency waves (as found during deep anesthesia)
  2. High-frequency beta activation (as found during light anesthesia)
  3. Suppressed EEG waves
  4. Burst suppression

It has numerical values from 0 to 100. with 0 representing isoelectric EEG and 100 being awake CNS. Recommended range of Bispectral index (BIS) for anesthesia: 40-60.

     60-80   Moderate sedation
     40-60 General anesthesia

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman undergoing surgery was intubated after administering rocuronium for neuromuscular blockade. Before anesthesia induction, a mechanosensor was incorporated with electrodes, as shown in the image below. The contraction of which muscle does it assess to monitor neuromuscular activity?
questions.solution:
The mechanosensor with electrodes is placed over the region of the ulnar nerve, thus assessing the contraction of the adductor pollicis muscle to monitor neuromuscular activity.

Monitoring of neuromuscular blockade is required to monitor the blockade intraoperatively, ensure its complete reversal postoperatively, and prevent residual blockade. To monitor the neuromuscular function, a peripheral motor nerve is supramaximally stimulated and the response of the muscle is assessed.

The most commonly assessed nerve-muscle unit is the ulnar nerve-adductor pollicis muscle. This is because it is easily accessible, has the lowest risk of direct muscle stimulation, and the response can be evaluated tactilely, visually, or by objective methods. To stimulate the ulnar nerve, the electrodes are best applied to the volar aspect of the wrist.

Other nerve-muscle units that can be assessed include:

  • Posterior tibial nerve-flexor hallucis brevis muscle
  • Facial nerve-orbicularis oculi muscle
  • Facial nerve-corrugator supercilii muscle

Many methods can be used for objective monitoring of neuromuscular function:

  • Mechanomyography (MMG)
  • Electromyography (EMG)
  • Acceleration of the muscle response (AMG)
  • Kinemyography (KMG)
  • Cuff pressure modality (CPM)
  • Compressomyography (CMG)
  • Phonomyography (PMG)

The image shows AMG, which is based on Newton’s second law: force = mass × acceleration. It measures the isotonic acceleration of the stimulated muscle.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient was posted for surgery under general anesthesia. He is a known case of type 1 diabetes and is on regular treatment with insulin detemir subcutaneously. What would you advise the patient regarding the dose of insulin that can be taken on the day of surgery?
questions.solution:
The dose of long-acting insulin that can be taken on the day of surgery in patients with type 1 diabetes is usually one-third the normal dose.

In the given clinical scenario, the patient is on insulin detemir which is a long-acting formulation of insulin. In a patient with type 1 diabetes on a long-acting formulation, the usual recommendation is to take one-third of the normal dose of long-acting insulin on the day of the surgery.

Other options:

Option A - The dose of all short-acting (e.g., regular) insulin is skipped on the day of the surgery.

Option C - One-half dose of insulin is taken in patients with type 2 diabetes on long-acting insulin or combination on the day of surgery.

Option D - A normal dose of insulin is recommended if the patient is on an insulin pump.

questions.text: Which of the following anaesthetic agents should be avoided in septic patients?
questions.solution:
Etomidate should be avoided in a patient with sepsis as it causes adrenocortical suppression.

Cortisol is the most abundant endogenous glucocorticoid. Physiologically, it increases vascular responsiveness to catecholamines and angiotensin II and has anti-inflammatory effects.

Etomidate transiently inhibits CYP11B1 (cortisol and corticosterone synthesis pathway) and CYP11B2 (in the aldosterone synthesis pathway). Etomidate is considered a very potent agent in inhibiting steroid production. Hence, it poses a risk of impairing a patient's ability to produce an adequate stress response. It increases the mortality risk in patients with sepsis.

Etomidate is an intravenous anesthetic agent. It depresses the reticular activating system and mimics the inhibitory effects of GABA. It has a rapid onset with a shorter duration of action. It does not affect myocardial function and can be used in patients with cardiac instability.

Adverse effects include post-operative nausea and vomiting, myoclonus, pain at the injection site, and transient acute adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for spinal anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Increased intracranial pressure is considered an absolute contraindication to spinal anesthesia because of the risk of brainstem herniation.

The other factors listed are considered relative contraindications.

Other options: 

Option B: Spinal stenosis  increases the risk of neurologic complications. However, a lower mass of local anesthetic reduces the risk in such patients.

Option C: Previous spine surgery does not necessarily increase the risk of neurologic complications. Factors such as postsurgical scarring and local anatomy are considered in such situations.

Option D: Peripheral neuropathy has not been found to be worsened by spinal anesthesia, and hence it is considered a relative contraindication.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old male patient presents with a heart rate of 45 beats/minute and blood pressure of 70/40 mmHg. According to the ACLS criteria, what is the next best step in the management of this patient?

ACLS - Advanced Cardiac Life Support
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is that of bradycardia and according to the ACLS criteria, the next best step in the management of this patient is the administration of a single dose of atropine. 

Bradycardia is defined as a heart rate of less than 60 beats/ min. Those who present with bradycardia should be first stabilized with the following:

  • Maintain patient airway and breathing
  • Administer oxygen if breathlessness is present
  • Cardiac monitor and blood pressure to be monitored with oximetry
  • IV access to be placed
  • 12 lead ECG done 

Following the initial stabilization, the patient should be checked for hypotension, altered mental status, signs of shock, angina, and acute heart failure. If none are present, then the patient can be monitored. If any of the above are present, then atropine 0.5 mg must be administered. This must be repeated every 3-5 minutes up to a maximum dose of 3mg. Atropine inhibits the muscarinic effects of the parasympathetic nervous system.

If the maximum dose of atropine has been administered and there is no response, then the next step is to initiate one of the following: 

  • Transcutaneous pacing (Option B) OR
  • Dopamine infusion at 5-20 mcg/minute (Option C) OR
  • Epinephrine infusion at 2-10 mcg/minute (Option D)

If the patient is not responding to treatment then expert consultation and transvenous pacing must be done.

Related Pearl: Adult Bradycardia with Pulse Algorithm

When a patient is in bradyarrhythmia typically with a heart rate of <50 bpm the initial intervention consists of identifying and treating the underlying cause. This includes: 

  • Maintaining a patent airway and assisting breathing as necessary
  • Administering oxygen if hypoxemic
  • Attaching cardiac monitor to identify rhythm; monitor blood pressure and oximetry
  • IV access
  • 12-Lead ECG

questions.text: An anesthetist used the airway device shown in the image given below on a patient. Which among the following statements is true regarding the adjunct?

choices.text: It can cause damage to the teeth
It can be used in conscious patients
It can be safely used in facial trauma cases

questions.solution:
The image shows a nasopharyngeal airway and its insertion. The true statement is that it can be used in conscious patients. 

A nasopharyngeal airway is used to provide artificial airway passage to the hypopharynx. To place a nasopharyngeal airway, the device should be lubricated and inserted into the nose with the bevel facing the nasal septum, at a 90-degree angle to the longitudinal axis of the body. It bypasses the gag reflex as they do not go through the mouth. Thus, it can be used in conscious patients or those who have been lightly anesthetized.

Care should be taken to avoid excessive force as damage to the nasal mucosa can result in epistaxis. The nasal approach should be avoided in conditions that put patients at higher risk for epistaxis. These conditions include but are not limited to coagulopathy, pregnancy, hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, and uncontrolled hypertension. Absolute contraindications include basilar skull fractures, facial trauma, midface disruption, and injury to the roof of the mouth.

An oropharyngeal airway is used to maintain the airway in anaesthetized patients. This adjunct prevents the tongue and epiglottis from falling back against the posterior pharynx and blocking the airway. They can cause coughing, retching, or laryngospasm in conscious patients.

To place an oropharyngeal airway, the device is inserted with the curved portion (concave) facing upwards. It is then rotated 180 degrees to be put in place. The below image shows the oropharyngeal airway:

Other options: 

Option A: Nasopharyngeal airways bypass the mouth so they do not cause damage to the teeth. Oropharyngeal airways can cause damage to the teeth. 

Option C: Nasopharyngeal airways can cause laryngospasm. Any foreign body that enters the nasal or oral cavities can cause local stimulation leading to reflex closure of the vocal cords. 

Option D: Its usage is contraindicated in facial trauma.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient underwent liposuction under local anesthesia. A few hours after the procedure, he presented with complaints of lassitude, shortness of breath, and slate grey cyanosis. The patient is started on 100 % oxygen, but the pulse oximeter still shows a saturation of 85%. Which of the following local anesthetic agents can most likely be attributed to his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with refractory hypoxemia (no change in saturation even on oxygen supplementation) points to a diagnosis of methemoglobinemia. The local anesthetic agent which can be attributed to his symptoms is prilocaine.

Prilocaine is metabolized to o-toluidine in the liver, which converts hemoglobin (Fe 2+) to methemoglobin (Fe 3+), hence producing methemoglobinemia. Therefore, the use of prilocaine is limited to dental procedures.

Methemoglobinemia is characterized by cyanosis which does not respond to oxygen administration. On examination, slate grey/ brownish pseudocyanosis can be seen.

Interestingly, pulse oximetry in methemoglobinemia shows a plateau of 80% to 85% irrespective of the arterial oxygen saturation and the methemoglobin levels. Co-oximeters which can differentiate methemoglobin from carboxyhemoglobin, oxyhemoglobin, and deoxyhemoglobin are thus preferred. Treatment of methemoglobinemia includes reduction of methemoglobin to hemoglobin by intravenous methylene blue (1–2 mg/kg).

Note: Benzocaine used in topical local anesthetic sprays can also cause methemoglobinemia.

  • Contraindicated in regional IV anesthesia

  • LA of choice in malignant hyperthermia
  • 1st synthetic LA
  • Metabolized to PABA, which have been associated with rare anaphylactic reactions

questions.text: While inducing anesthesia in a patient posted for neurosurgery, the consultant advises you to use an anesthetic agent with a lower MAC. The minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) of an inhaled anesthetic agent is a measure of its:
questions.solution:
The minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) of an inhalational anesthetic agent is an indicator of its potency. An anesthetic agent with a lower MAC is advised in this patient. The lower the MAC, the higher the potency. 

MAC is an account of the alveolar concentration of the anesthetic that prevents movement in 50% of patients in response to a standardized stimulus such as a surgical incision. It is representative of the partial pressure of the anesthetic in the brain and is helpful in the comparison of the potencies of different agents. MAC is relatively unaffected by species, sex, or duration of anesthesia.

MAC values (expressed as a '%' of 1 atmosphere) of some anesthetic agents are:

  • Halothane - 0.75
  • Isoflurane - 1.2
  • Sevoflurane - 2.0
  • Desflurane - 6.0
  • N2O - 105

Note: N2O is not used alone as a complete anesthetic agent, because of a high MAC. It is generally used in combination with the more potent agents. Such a combination will reduce the requirements of the other agents (65% nitrous oxide decreases the MAC of the volatile anesthetics by approximately 50%).

questions.text: A patient is set to undergo surgery.  His past medical records reveal that he is homozygotic for the atypical pseudocholinesterase. Which of the following would you expect to encounter in this patient on administering succinylcholine?

choices.text: A rapid onset of action and a short duration of action
Delayed onset and a short duration of action

questions.solution:
A prolonged duration of action of succinylcholine would be expected in a patient with atypical pseudocholinesterase enzyme.

Succinylcholine is rapidly metabolized by pseudocholinesterase as soon as it enters the circulation. This results in the short duration of action of succinylcholine, which is usually less than 10 minutes. 

Abnormal pseudocholinesterase, resulting from homozygous or heterozygous gene defect, cannot metabolize succinylcholine efficiently, leading to a prolonged duration of action. In patients heterozygous for the atypical pseudocholinesterase, the duration of action is prolonged modestly (2–20 minutes) whereas in homozygotes it may be prolonged up to 4–8 hours. The incidence of atypical pseudocholinesterase genes is more common in those with European ancestry.

The rapid onset of action of succinylcholine is because of its small volume of distribution resulting from very low lipid solubility. The onset is not affected by the atypical pseudocholinesterase.

questions.text: A middle-aged man is posted for an open cholecystectomy. He has a medical history of hypercholesterolemia. The pre-anesthetic evaluation revealed abnormal liver function tests and mild hepatomegaly. Which of the following muscle relaxants can be safely used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Atracurium can be safely used in this patient with liver disease because of non-hepatic metabolism.

Atracurium and cis-atracurium undergo plasma ester hydrolysis and Hofmann elimination at physiological pH and temperature. Hofmann elimination is a spontaneous, non-enzymatic, chemical degradation. So, the clearance of atracurium and cis-atracurium is independent of liver or kidney function. Hence, they are the agents of choice in patients with liver disease and/or renal failure.

The metabolites of atracurium and cis-atracurium are monoquaternary acrylate and laudanosine.

Some of the adverse effects of atracurium are hypotension, tachycardia, and allergic reactions (bronchospasm) due to a dose-dependent histamine release. On the other hand, these adverse effects are not seen with cis-atracurium and so it is preferred over the former.

Pancuronium, rocuronium, and vecuronium are dependent on the liver for excretion.

questions.text: You are about to administer neostigmine to a patient for reversal of neuromuscular blockade. Your senior asks you to add atropine to it. This is because atropine _______.

choices.text: Facilitates earlier recovery from neuromuscular blockade

questions.solution:
Atropine, a tertiary amine, is an anticholinergic drug that is used along with anticholinesterases like neostigmine in order to minimize the muscarinic adverse effects of anticholinesterases. It has no effect on the reversal of neuromuscular blockade produced by the nicotinic effect of anticholinesterases.

Atropine counteracts the cardiovascular effects of anticholinesterases like bradycardia and other bradyarrhythmias.

Glycopyrrolate, a quaternary amine, is another anticholinergic that can be used with anticholinesterases. It has a slower onset than atropine but does not cause central effects as it does not cross the blood-brain barrier, unlike atropine.

questions.text: While undergoing a surgical procedure under halothane anesthesia, a patient suddenly develops hyperthermia and muscle rigidity. Following prompt measures, the patient recovers. Considering this history, which of the following anesthetic agents should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient developing hyperthermia and muscle rigidity while undergoing a procedure under halothane anesthesia is suggestive of an episode of malignant hyperthermia. Desflurane should be avoided in malignant hyperthermia.

Inhaled anesthetics, such as halothane, isoflurane, sevoflurane, desflurane, ether, and methoxyflurane, and depolarizing muscle relaxants, such as succinylcholine, are known to trigger malignant hyperthermia; hence, these drugs should be avoided in a patient with prior history of malignant hyperthermia.

Malignant hyperthermia is a genetic condition in which mutated RyR1 receptors are present in the skeletal muscles. In the presence of certain triggers, this mutated RyR1 causes an uncontrolled increase in intracellular calcium in the skeletal muscle, resulting in sustained muscle contraction, rigidity, increased heat production, acidosis, hyperkalemia, and increased end-tidal CO2. Susceptible patients are those with a positive family history (inherited as an autosomal dominant trait) and those with congenital myopathies.

Dantrolene sodium is the drug of choice for the management of malignant hyperthermia. Once the diagnosis is made, the causative inhalational agent should be stopped immediately. Supportive treatment with rapid cooling, inhalation of 100% oxygen, control of acidosis, and treatment of hyperkalemia should be given.

Related Pearl: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

  • Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis
  • Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia
  • Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria
  • Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

  • Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2
  • Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).
  • Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 
  • Cooling the patient

questions.text: Which of the following is the most commonly used IV induction agent in a patient requiring caesarean section?
questions.solution:
Propofol is the most common intravenous induction agent used in general anesthesia for cesarean delivery.

Propofol can induce unconsciousness in approximately 45 seconds. Its administration does not affect neonatal Apgar scores with typical intravenous induction doses (2-2.5 mg/kg). Repeated or larger cumulative doses (9 mg/kg) are associated with significant newborn depression.

Other options:

Option B: Thiopentone was the most commonly used agent for induction before the introduction of propofol.

Option C: Etomidate is not used as it can induce seizures in patients with reduced seizure thresholds. It is also associated with a higher incidence of nausea and vomiting.

Option D: Ketamine is the preferred agent for patients with hemodynamic compromise as it helps maintain arterial pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output due to central stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system.

questions.text: Endotracheal intubation has been planned in a 6-year-old child. The type of laryngoscope blade that would be preferred for this procedure would be:
questions.solution:
Miller's laryngoscope blade would be preferred while performing an endotracheal intubation in a 6-year-old child.

A laryngoscope is an instrument used for examination of the larynx and facilitation of tracheal intubation. It has three components: the handle, the blade, and the light source.

Miller's blade is a straight blade. As the larynx is located higher in the neck in children compared to adults, a straight blade is preferred over a curved blade. Its curve begins 2 inches from the tip. It is inserted using the para-glossal technique that helps avoid contact with the maxillary incisors and also provides maximal tongue control.

It is used in:

  • Neonates, infants, and young children
  • Adults with short thyromental distance and long floppy epiglottis.

Other options:

Option B: The McCoy blade is a modification of a Macintosh blade. Its design allows the tip to be flexed, by using the lever alongside the handle. This helps to lift the epiglottis without the degree of force that would be required using a standard blade. It helps make some difficult intubations easier.

Option C: The Macintosh blade is a sharply curved blade with a large flange. It is inserted in the right side of the mouth, and the flange is used to sweep the tongue to the left. The blade is advanced and positioned in the vallecula. Advantages of a curved blade include:

  • Greater room available for the passage of an endotracheal tube
  • Less damage to the teeth

Option D: The D-blade is a highly curved blade used in video-laryngoscopy.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male patient is set to undergo a daycare procedure. Which of the following statements regarding daycare procedure are incorrect?
  1. Intravenous (IV) anesthetic agent of choice is propofol
  2. Inhalational anesthetic of choice is sevoflurane.
  3. The preferred muscle relaxant used is succinylcholine.
  4. Thiopental is the preferred intravenous anesthetic.
  5. Morphine increases the risk of postoperative nausea and vomiting
questions.solution:
Statements 3 and 4 are incorrect.

The correct statements are:

  • Intravenous (IV) anesthetic agent of choice is propofol
  • Inhalational anesthetic of choice is sevoflurane.
  • Morphine increases the risk of postoperative nausea and vomiting.

Day surgery is defined as the admission and discharge of a patient for a specific procedure within a 12-hour working day. Success in day surgery requires each component of the pathway to be safe and efficient and to be performed in sequence. Unplanned overnight admissions are minimized by ensuring that:

  • The patient is informed and fit for the procedure
  • The procedure itself is achievable as a day case
  • The procedure is scheduled early on the operating list to allow safe recovery and discharge
  • The home environment can support a postoperative ambulatory patient.

Anesthetic considerations:

The IV anesthetic of choice for daycare surgery is propofol due to its smooth induction and rapid recovery. The antiemetic action is also beneficial. Thiopental results in prolonged postoperative sedation and is not preferred in ambulatory anesthesia Benzodiazepines and ketamine are avoided for similar reasons.

The inhalational anesthetic of choice for daycare surgery is sevoflurane. The low blood-gas partition coefficient, blood-brain coefficient, and minimal airway irritation of sevoflurane promote rapid induction and rapid recovery. Desflurane is also associated with faster recovery but its irritant effect on the upper airway with risk of laryngospasm prevents its use as an induction agent.

Rocuronium is an intermediate-acting muscle relaxant with a rapid onset which is used in daycare anesthesia to facilitate endotracheal intubation and provide surgical relaxation. Its actions can be terminated by the reversal agent sugammadex which produces a rapid and complete reversal of neuromuscular blockade.

Succinylcholine is the shortest-acting muscle relaxant but it has a high incidence of postoperative myalgia. So its use in daycare anesthesia is discouraged.

Analgesics: Paracetamol and other NSAIDs are preferred to manage pain in daycare procedures since opioids increase the risk of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV). However, short-acting opioids like remifentanil can be used if adequate pain control is not achieved with NSAIDs. Morphine is a long-acting opioid and therefore it should be avoided in daycare surgery to reduce the incidence of PONV.

questions.text: Which of the following methods of anesthesia requires injecting a local anesthetic at the point shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a block being administered at the sacral hiatus, which is suggestive of a caudal block done in caudal anesthesia. 

Caudal anesthesia is a common regional technique done in pediatric patients. The posterior superior iliac spines create an equilateral triangle, with the sacral hiatus located at its apex. Ultrasonography is useful to help guide correct needle placement. The sacrococcygeal ligament, which lies above the sacral hiatus, usually gets calcified with age; hence, caudal anesthesia is not preferred in adults.

The procedure is used when a sacral anesthetic spread is desired (eg. in perineal or anal procedures).

Other options: 

Option A: A lumbar plexus blockade, or psoas compartment block, is a regional anesthesia technique used for pain relief in hip, thigh, and knee surgeries. It involves injecting local anesthetic near the lumbar plexus, blocking pain signals and reducing the need for systemic pain medications. This block is especially useful for postoperative pain management and for patients who cannot tolerate general anesthesia.

Option B: In the epidural type of anesthesia, the needle is inserted into the epidural space, and the position of the needle is confirmed by a sudden loss of resistance (as the needle passes through the ligamentum flavum). 

Option D: A parasacral nerve block is a regional anesthesia technique used to provide pain relief for surgeries involving the lower limb and perineum. It involves injecting local anesthetic near the sacral plexus, effectively blocking pain signals from the targeted area. This block offers significant pain relief and minimizes the need for systemic analgesics, making it useful for postoperative pain management and patients who cannot undergo general anesthesia.

A 65-year-old male with an inguinal hernia is planned for TAPP repair under general anesthesia. On pre-operative evaluation, which of the following predictors suggests that airway intubation is difficult?

TAPP - Transabdominal preperitoneal

choices.text: Able to bite upper lip with lower incisors

questions.solution:
The thyromental distance of <6 cm is a predictor of difficult intubation. 

Inter-incisor distance of <3cm is a predictor for difficult airway. 

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man who underwent an emergent laparotomy for hollow viscus perforation was admitted to the ICU. He screened positive for being at high risk of postoperative delirium. What should be the next best step to prevent postoperative delirium?
questions.solution:
Multicomponent nonpharmacologic measures is considered the best initial step for both preventing and managing postoperative delirium (POD).

The following measures are taken for the prevention of postoperative delirium in high-risk patients:

  • Frequent reorientation to time, place, and person
  • Cognitive and sensory stimulation with simple and good communication
  • Maintaining the patient's sleep-wake cycle
  • Avoidance of deliriogenic medications (eg. anticholinergics, sedatives, hypnotics)

In delirious patients, nonpharmacologic interventions are the initial mode of management:

  • frequent reorientation in a calm environment
  • avoiding unnecessary use of restraints
  • bringing familiar objects (such as glasses and hearing aids) that the patient uses

Additionally, patients are evaluated for possible precipitating factors of delirium. These include uncontrolled pain, hypoxia, infections, and electrolyte abnormalities. 

Pharmacologic measures are used in the lowest effective dose for agitated patients when the above interventions have failed. The medication of choice is haloperidol. Alternatively, atypical antipsychotics (eg. risperidone, olanzapine, quetiapine) can also be used.

questions.text: Halothane hepatitis is a potentially fatal condition with a high mortality rate. Which of the following best explains the underlying mechanism of the condition?
questions.solution:
Halothane hepatitis is an immune-mediated hypersensitivity reaction due to antibodies against trifluoroacetyl-modified proteins.

The incidence is rare, but it is highly fatal with a mortality of 50-75%. This is why most countries do not use halothane in adult patients.

The condition is associated with the oxidative metabolism of halothane. This results in the formation of the highly reactive compound trifluoroacetyl chloride. This compound reacts with nearby liver proteins and acts as a neoantigen. The liver damage is linked to an immune response against this modified protein. Patients who develop this condition often have a history of prior exposure to halothane which results in sensitization.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with congenital insensitivity to pain. He was explained that the condition is similar to being administered a local anesthetic which prevents the opening of the sodium channels. Which of the following phases of the nerve action potential will be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Congenital insensitivity to pain (CIPA) can be associated with defective sodium channels. Local anesthetics also prevent the opening of the voltage-gated sodium channels. This results in a failure of nerve depolarization. In the given graph, phase B occurs due to the opening of the sodium channels. This phase is likely to be affected in this patient.

Mutations in the neuronal sodium channels can either result in spontaneous pain or impairment of pain sensitivity. For example, mutations in the sodium channel Nav1.7 result in loss of function of the sodium channel and CIPA. In contrast, activating mutations can result in paroxysmal extreme pain disorder.


Point A - Resting potential. A state where both Na+ and K+ channels are closed. 

Point B - Threshold potential. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus and Na+ influx occurs. The initiation of action potential occurs only after a certain potential is reached, called the threshold potential.

Point C - Peak of the action potential. Na+ channels close and K+ channels open, causing repolarization due to K+ efflux. 

Point D - Repolarization and hyperpolarization due to continued  K+ efflux.

Point E - After Hyperpolarization. The K+ channels slowly return to the closed state, causing after-hyperpolarization. Na+ channels are reset and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus.

Both channels then close and the membrane returns to resting membrane potential.

questions.text:
Choose the correct statement regarding the oxygen delivery rate and the advantage of using the device shown below.

PEEP - positive end-expiratory pressure
questions.solution:
The correct statement regarding the oxygen delivery rate and the advantage of using high-flow nasal cannula is that it delivers oxygen at 40-60 L/min and increases positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP).

High flow nasal cannula is a mode of respiratory support used in the management of acute respiratory failure. It delivers humidified gas via the nasal cannula at high flow rates.

  • HFNC can deliver oxygen at 40L/min, 37°C, and 99.9% relative humidity.
  • The high-flow oxygen is delivered directly to the nasopharynx. This produces FiO2 equal to that delivered by traditional mask devices.

Advantages of using a high-flow nasal cannula are:

  • Soft and pliable nasal prongs provide comfort to the patient.
  • Warming and humidification of secretions: The heating of air to core temperature and humidification of the inspired air is better at high flow. The humidification causes increased water content in the secretions, which facilitates the removal of secretions. It also decreases the work of breathing and avoids airway desiccation and epithelial injury.
  • Reduces dead space: The high flow of the oxygen delivered clears the upper airway of the expired air, which reduces dead space by a decrease of rebreathing and allows a higher fraction of minute ventilation to participate in alveolar gas exchange.
  • Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP): HFNC increases the positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP), and reduces the work of breathing.
  • High flow rate causes decreased entrainment of room air, allowing more accurate delivery of oxygen.

questions.text: The mask given below is preferred in which of the following patients?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a venturi mask and it is preferred in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

There is hypoventilation in patients with COPD and they require greater FiO2 than those provided by low-flow devices. Thus, they are ideal candidates for the use of a Venturi mask. The Venturi mask uses the Bernoulli principle to deliver a predetermined and fixed concentration of oxygen to the patient that is based on the size of the constriction present in the device. A fixed oxygen concentration is delivered irrespective of the patient's respiratory pattern as it provides a higher gas flow than the peak inspiratory flow rate.

In the Venturi mask system, oxygen inflow is connected to a specific color-coded entrainment device at the base of the mask that provides a set Fio2 at a set oxygen inflow rate. The range provided by different devices is Fio2 of 0.24 to 0.5, oxygen inflow of 4 to 15 l/min, and the total flow delivered 35 to 45 l/min.

Disadvantages: Caution should be exercised when handling the mask as there can be an increase in the delivered FiO2 when the air entrainment ports are obstructed by the patient’s hands, bed sheets, or water condensate.

questions.text: Desflurane is not preferred for inhalational anesthetic induction in children. This is because of:

choices.text: Dose dependent decrease in blood pressure
High solubility leading to delayed emergence

questions.solution:
Desflurane is a highly pungent gas associated with an increased incidence of laryngospasm if used for inhalational induction in children. Hence, it is not used as an induction agent.

It has lower blood solubility, which leads to a more rapid emergence. That is why it can be used in obese patients and neurosurgical procedures where rapid awakening is required for neurological function assessment. It decreases systemic vascular resistance and mean arterial blood pressure in a dose-dependent fashion.

Sevoflurane is the preferred choice for anesthesia induction in children. However, it can sometimes cause epileptiform changes in the EEG. The clinical significance of these changes is unclear.

An unresponsive child is brought to the emergency room. His BP is not recordable and pulse rate is 40 per minute. CPR is initiated. Despite proper oxygenation and ventilation, his SpO2 is 70% and pulse rate is not improving. What is the dose of epinephrine that needs to be given to the child?

CPR - Cardio-pulmonary resuscitation
questions.solution:
In a child who continues to have bradycardia despite initiating CPR, the dose of epinephrine that needs to be given is 0.01 mg/kg of 1:10,000 solution (0.1 mL/kg of 1:10,000). 

Epinephrine can be given intravenously or via the intraosseous route if the intravenous route is not accessible. It is repeated every 3-5 minutes. If intravenous or intraosseous access cannot be obtained, then it can be administered via the endotracheal route at a dose of 0.1 mg/kg of 1:1,000 solution (0.1 mL/kg of 1:1000).

questions.text: A G2P1 lady with 37 weeks of gestation is in active labor. You assist your labor room resident in giving a pudendal block. The resident explains that you have to approach the nerve by identifying a particular surface landmark. The landmark for this nerve block is:
questions.solution:
The ischial spine is the landmark for the pudendal nerve block. This is because the pudendal nerve is accessible here as it passes below the sacrospinous ligament at the level of attachment of the ligament to the ischial spine.

Sensory nerve fibers of the pudendal nerve arise from S2, S3, and S4 nerves. Pudendal nerve blocks in combination with local anesthetic are used to provide perineal anesthesia during the second stage of labor.

Here, a special needle (Koback)  and a guide (Iowa trumpet) are used. The needle is placed transvaginally underneath the ischial spine on each side and is advanced 1 to 1.5 cm through the sacrospinous ligament. 10 mL of 1% lidocaine or 2% chloroprocaine is used for the procedure.

The pudendal nerve block can be used for:

  • Analgesia during the second stage of labor. A pudendal block is used when there are contraindications to epidural/ spinal anesthesia or if there is a need for low vaginal and perineal anesthesia.
  • Episiotomy repair
  • Minor procedures of the lower vagina and perineum.
  • Instrumental delivery.

The complications of the procedure are accidental intravascular injection, retro-psoas abscess, subgluteal abscess, and retroperitoneal hematoma.

Also, note that the pudendal block does not impact the cervix or upper vagina and is ineffective for pain relief associated with uterine manipulation.

questions.text: What is the maneuver being performed in the given image?
questions.solution:
The maneuver performed in the given image is jaw-thrust. It is an important technique in emergency airway management to open up the airway, particularly in patients with a cervical spine injury.

The airway is usually obstructed by posterior displacement of the tongue or epiglottis. The Jaw-thrust maneuver moves the tongue anteriorly with the mandible, reducing the obstruction of the airway by the tongue. Both hands of the clinician are placed on either side of the patient’s head and the angles of the jaw are grasped and lifted. It can be performed in a patient with cervical injury but caution must be followed to not hyperextend the neck.

The sequence of BLS is circulation (chest compression), airway, and then breathing as per the AHA 2020 guidelines.

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for brain death, except:
questions.solution:
All the options are criteria for brain death, except absent deep tendon reflexes. Deep tendon reflexes/ spinal cord reflexes may be present in brain death as the spinal cord function below C1 is intact. 

Clinical criteria for brain death:

  • Coma- Deep, unresponsiveness to noxious stimuli

  • Absence of brainstem reflexes- Pupillary, oculocephalic, corneal, gag reflex, etc.
  • Apnea- Absence of spontaneous respiration at  arterial pCO2 tension of at least 50–60 mmHg

  • Isoelectric electroencephalogram
  • Absence of somatosensory evoked potentials and brainstem evoked potentials 
  • Absence of cerebral perfusion, as documented by angiographic, transcranial Doppler, or radioisotopic studies

questions.text:
An intern in the anesthesia department was asked about the use of absorbents like soda lime in breathing systems. Which of the following statements are true regarding soda lime?
  1. Soda lime is less commonly used than barium hydroxide lime.
  2. The end products of the reaction of soda lime and CO2 are Na2CO3 + Ca(OH)2.
  3. The major constituent of soda lime is Ca(OH)2.
  4. Water content of soda lime is 5%.
  5. KOH is one of the components of soda lime.
questions.solution:
The statements that are true regarding soda lime are 3 and 5.

Soda lime is a CO2 absorbent used in the circle system (breathing system). It can absorb up to 23 L of CO2 per 100 g of absorbent. Its major constituent is Ca(OH)2 (80%). Other components include KOH, NaOH, and water (15%). It is also known as slaked lime.

A circle system is used in place of Mapleson circuits to avoid problems like loss of patient heat and humidity, waste of anesthetic agent due to high fresh gas flow, and pollution of the operating room environment. Components of this system are:

  1. CO2 absorber containing CO2 absorbent
  2. Fresh gas inlet
  3. Inspiratory unidirectional valve and inspiratory breathing tube
  4. Y-connector
  5. Expiratory unidirectional valve and expiratory breathing tube
  6. Adjustable pressure-limiting valve
  7. Reservoir

The reactions of soda lime granules with CO2 are as follows:

Step 1: CO2 + H2O (present on and within granules) → H2CO3

Step 2: 

  • H2CO3 + 2NaOH → Na2CO3 + 2H2O + Heat
  • H2CO3 + 2KOH → K2CO3 + 2H2O + Heat

All available strong bases are depleted.

Step 3:

  • Na2CO3 + Ca(OH)2 → CaCO3 (insoluble) + 2NaOH + Heat
  • K2CO3 + Ca(OH)2 → CaCO3 (insoluble) + 2KOH + Heat

NaOH and KOH are regenerated in this step, thereby acting as catalysts. This is the rate-limiting step since the NaOH and KOH regenerated in this step are required for step 2 for additional CO2 to be dissolved in water (step 1). Byproducts of this entire reaction are water and heat.

A pH indicator dye changes color from white to purple due to increasing H+ concentration and absorbent depletion. The absorbent should be replaced when 50-70% has changed color.

Absorbent granules can absorb and later release volatile anesthetics. This property is enhanced by the increased dryness of soda lime. Volatile anesthetics can be broken down to CO, resulting in clinically significant CO poisoning. Another absorbent, barium hydroxide lime, is no longer used due to the risk of fire in the system.

questions.text: During the pre-anaesthetic evaluation of a patient, the oral cavity examined is depicted in the image given below. The image shows which class of the Mallampati score?
questions.solution:
The image of the oral cavity shows the soft palate and the base of the uvula, and is thus graded as Mallampati class III.

Mallampati classification is an important component of airway examination. It is used to assess the visibility of the faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate in an upright position with the patient's head neutral, mouth open, tongue protruded, and no phonation. 

Higher scores indicate poor visibility of these structures due to the presence of a large tongue. Thus, Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati classes III and IV are considered features of difficult airway.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

questions.solution:
The image shows a local anesthetic being injected into the tip of the axilla around the axillary artery. This is the method used to perform the axillary block. The nerves blocked are the ulnar, radial, and median nerves. 

The axillary block is used for elbow and distal upper extremity anesthesia. The most important landmark is the pulse of the axillary artery just distal to the pectoralis major near the anterior axillary wall. Usually, the median, ulnar, and radial nerves (close the arterial wall) and the musculocutaneous nerve (showing a characteristic medial-to-lateral course in the axilla) can be seen.

Although this is a safe and effective technique, the musculocutaneous nerve fails to be blocked as it changes its course from adjacent the axillary artery to within the coracobrachialis muscle and then exiting the muscle. However, this can be prevented by ultrasound imaging, which helps in direct visualization of the nerve. 

The arm to be blocked should be abducted at 90° and the forearm may be supported horizontally at 90° or above or behind the head for optimal positioning of the patient for the procedure.

A 36-year-old female patient is posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. She forgot the instruction of being nil per oral and had breakfast a few hours back. The anesthetist decides to use the device shown below to reduce the risk of gastric aspiration. Identify the device used.

LMA - Laryngeal mask airway
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the LMA Supreme.

The LMA Supreme (SLMA) is a single-use, second-generation supraglottic airway device, identified by the presence of a modified cuff design, a drainage tube that allows for gastric access, an integrated bite block, and a fixation tab.

The fixation tab should rest 1-2.5 cm above the upper lip and help in the determination of the proper size of SLMA to be used. It helps in an improved perilaryngeal seal when the cheek is taped across the fixation tab. SLMA is based on the LMA ProSeal (PLMA) variant. Studies suggest that second-generation LMAs such as the SLMA and PLMA reduced the risk of gastric aspiration. 

The property of preventing gastric aspiration along with the improved airway seal and higher leak pressures have enabled supraglottic airway devices to be used in various applications where the classic LMAs (cLMA) are potentially unsuitable. Such situations include non-supine positions, laparoscopic surgeries like cholecystectomy, and in patients who are obese. The successful, routine use of the SLMA in fasted, nonobese patients for cesarean section has also been reported.

An image of LMA Supreme is given below:


Other options:

Option A - LMA ProSeal (PLMA) is a second-generation re-usable supraglottic airway. It is identified by the presence of a gastric drainage tube that allows for gastric access with an orogastric tube, bite block, and a softer cuff. The fixation tab is absent in PLMA.

The orogastric tube diverts regurgitated gastric contents away from the airway, effectively isolating the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts. PLMA and SLMA can be used to provide positive pressure ventilations up to 30cm H2O.

An image of PLMA is given below:


Option C - Classic LMA is the prototype and most widely used supraglottic device. It is identified by the presence of an oval-shaped, silicone mask with an inflatable cuff that sits in the hypopharynx and forms a seal around the periglottic tissues.

It does not have any port for gastric access. The seal formed around the laryngeal inlet allows for the delivery of oxygen and inhaled anesthetics permits positive pressure ventilations up to 20 cm H2O. The cLMA is reusable up to 40 times.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man involved in a road traffic accident was brought to the emergency room. His vitals are as shown below. His vitals did not improve on fluid resuscitation. On FAST examination, there was fluid present in the retroperitoneal space. The patient was shifted to the operating room for laparotomy. What is the intravenous agent of choice for this patient?
  • Pulse rate- 100 bpm
  • Blood pressure(BP)- 80/40 mmHg
  • SpO2- 95%
  • Respiratory rate- 30 per minute
  • GCS- 15/15

(FAST- Focussed Assessment of Sonography in Trauma)
questions.solution:
Ketamine is the intravenous agent of choice in this patient. Ketamine indirectly stimulates the cardiovascular system and is thus useful in this patient as he has come with a traumatic injury to the abdomen and is hemodynamically unstable.

Ketamine is a phencyclidine derivative that inhibits NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate) receptors resulting in a decrease in excitatory stimulation by glutamate in the brain. It is a strong analgesic and amnestic agent. It also causes dissociative anesthesia.

On the cardiovascular system, it directly has a cardio-depressive effect and indirectly stimulates it by activating the sympathetic system and inhibiting the vagus nerve. It predominantly shows a stimulatory effect hence causing tachycardia, increased cardiac output, and increased systemic and pulmonary hypertension.

On the respiratory system, it has a bronchodilator effect on bronchial smooth muscles. It increases salivary secretion and bronchial secretion. It also acts on other systems and increases the intracranial and intraocular pressures.

Uses:

  • Ketamine is the intravenous agent of choice for patients with shock, low cardiac output states, and reactive airway diseases.
  • It is also used in patients with congenital heart diseases, especially with right-to-left shunts
  • Perioperative analgesia

Ketamine should be avoided in patients with a history of seizures, psychiatric illness, or vascular aneurysms. It is also contraindicated in open eye injuries and eye surgeries

Adverse effects:

  • Hallucination is the most common side effect of ketamine.
  • Emergence reaction (vivid dreaming, illusion, etc)
  • Increases brain oxygen consumption and metabolic rate leading to increased intracranial tension.

Other options:

Option B: Propofol is the most commonly used parenteral anesthetic. It is cerebro-protective by decreasing cerebral metabolic rate. It produces dose-dependent hypotension.

Option C: Thiopentone belongs to the barbiturate group. It is cerebro-protective and is an anticonvulsant. It leads to hypotension due to vasodilation. It is contraindicated in patients with obstructive airway disease, severe cardiovascular instability, and shock, history of porphyrias.

Option D: Midazolam is a benzodiazepine. It is used in treating seizures and is used in daycare surgeries as an induction agent due to its short half-life.

  • Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.
  • Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.
  • Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.
  • Prevention by thinner needle

Management:

  • Supine position
  • IV fluids
  • Caffeine and analgesia
  • Epidural blood patch

Related Pearl: Factors That Can Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Age: Younger, more frequent
  • Sex: Females > males
  • Needle size: Larger > smaller
  • Needle bevel: Less when the needle bevel is placed in the long axis of the neuraxis Orienting a needle bevel parallel with the axis of the spine, such that the longitudinal fibers of the dura would more likely be separated than cut, results in a lower incidence of postspinal puncture headache
  • Pregnancy: More when pregnant
  • Dural punctures: More with multiple punctures

Factors That Do Not Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Insertion and use of catheters for continuous spinal anesthesia
  • Timing of ambulation

questions.text: In a child with difficult intravenous cannulation, an emergency intraosseous infusion is made through the tibia. What is the ideal site for inserting the needle in this tibial intraosseous infusion?

choices.text: Below the tibial tuberosity at a 45° angle towards the epiphyseal plate
Below the tibial tuberosity at a 45° angle away from epiphyseal plate
Above the tibial tuberosity at a 45° angle towards the epiphyseal plate
Above the tibial tuberosity at a 45° angle away from epiphyseal plate

questions.solution:
In tibial intraosseous infusion, a needle is inserted 2–3 cm below the tibial tuberosity at a 45° angle away from the epiphyseal plate.

Intraosseous access involves placing a catheter into the marrow venous plexus and administering crystalloids, colloids, drugs and blood which leads to rapid and reliable absorption into the systemic circulation. It provides emergency access to the venous circulation in pediatric patients by way of the large medullary venous channels. The needle is directed away from the epiphyseal plate to minimize the risk of injury.

The disadvantage of this route is the risk of osteomyelitis, compartment syndrome, and bone marrow or fat embolism.

questions.text: Gas from which of the following cylinders can be used in patients with acute exacerbation of bronchial asthma along with oxygen?
questions.solution:
The gas in the cylinder with a brown shoulder and body is helium. Helium along with oxygen, together known as heliox can be used in the treatment of acute exacerbation of bronchial asthma as they decrease the work of breathing. Heliox can be used to deliver inhaled 𝛃2 agonists in patients with severe critical asthma.

Principle:

  • When the flow across the bronchus is laminar, the flow rate increases as the gas viscosity decreases.
  • In airway obstructing conditions, where there is turbulent flow, the flow rate decreases as the gas density increases. Hence helium, having low density is added with oxygen to increase the flow rate. It decreases the resistance in the airways and improves ventilation and gas exchange.

The other options represent general anaesthetics and are not useful in treating bronchial asthma.

  • Violet: Ethylene
  • Blue: N2O
  • Orange: Cyclopropane
